The serial interval was defined as the interval between disease onset in an index case and disease onset in a person infected by that index case. The serial interval distribution used for this estimation was a gamma distribution with a mean of 14.5 days and a standard deviation of 5 days, with intervals rounded to the nearest whole number of days, consistent with the understanding that the serial interval of EVD cases ranges from 3 to 36 days with mean 14 to 15 days.[ 11, 34– 36] Given that serial interval distribution, which we can denote as a probability w(t) of a t-day interval between given primary and secondary cases, Wallinga-Teunis estimation works by defining a relative likelihood p
